review_title: Good Place to Work Depending on Who You are Working With
job_title: Registered Nurse BSN in Toronto, ON
pros: -Helpful nurses who still like their job -Helpful PSP's who know their job and like to work -Teamwork at times -Good atmosphere to work on unit at times -Mostly good doctors who listen on rounds and appreciate nursing input
cons: -Parking rates are excessive for visitors $27.50/day and staff $13.50/shift -Nothing healthy to eat during the day (or night) and terribly long lineups that cut into your short break times, so you ALWAYS have to bring your own food -On the Ross Tilley Burn Unit - nurses who badger and harangue newer nurses with impunity, because it's the culture to let senior nurses swear or carry on unprofessionally in the unit workplace -Entitled PSP's on many units who choose which nurses to help, and who to ignore, thereby interfering with proper patient care -staffing shortages from nurses who left because they are fed up with the lack of leadership and oversight of the toxicity of the unit -staffing shortages requiring agency nurses who are sometimes mistreated with heavy patient assignments and need help from other staff nurses (who are busy themselves)

review_title: Great work soured by terrible management
pros: Solid pay, good benefits, interesting work, flexible, excellent team
cons: Little to no growth opportunities. Work was very undervalued by direct management and senior leadership. There was an expectation to take on additional work without compensation, and during significant personnel changes, there was little transparency or direction. I can’t in good conscience recommend anyone work in this department at Sunnybrook right now; there is no relevant expertise at senior leadership and no real desire to listen to the team members.

It was a terrible environment to work in and to watch how some patients were treated.  This dr allowed student Drs to practice on patients and hurt them and this was unacceptable. I reported the dr.

cons: There are no cons. It is the best!

review_title: The best research and teaching hospital to work in Toronto
pros:
-Fantastic place to gain research and patient experience and build your skills
-There are weekly Clinical Rounds and monthly educational talks/conferences to attend
-You get to meet and work with a variety of health professionals and in multidisciplinary teams 
-HOOPP organization (yes, you get docked a lot from each pay, but trust me it is worth it in the end because with your employer matching or contributing more, it adds up quickly! When I left Sunnybrook after two years, I had ~$9,000 to transfer into my RRSP!!) 
-Full dental and medical benefits package with vacation pay (even when a contract employee)
-High job security/stability because contract positions are almost always renewed for min 1-2 years (dependent on job performance, of course)
-Free downtown and uptown shuttle bus (saves you from having to purchase the hefty ~$145 TTC metro monthly pass!!) 
-Less bureaucracy (unlike CAMH)
cons:
-Pay compensation is arbitrarily set with very little negotiation as opposed to a standardization of pay commensurate of education and experience. 
-Difficult to get pay raises (even when you do get one, it is not very much; .20 more an hr)
-Sometimes you get talked down to by doctors and other "higher up" staff (this isn't necessarily specific to Sunnybrook)

pros: good salary and benefits . good pension plan
cons: bad management some managers are too naive

review_title: Great Pay.... but that's about it
job_title: Patient Administration Assistant in North York, ON
pros: Great pay, fast paced, days are never the same. I worked in Emergency and some days were good (in that there weren't any traumas because it sucks when someone is in a life or death situation). Feels rewarding, given I'm certainly not a doctor. But it feels like I am helping the sick, even if I'm not the one healing them
cons:
Training schedule was not good... I booked off time from my full time job to train for a week. They changed it last minute (literally told us the change the first day of training) and I could not complete my last course. They were unwilling to help me find another day to accommodate me completing it, and because of that, I was not being paid the night-shift premiums. I tried partnering with the person who would run the last course but she was unwilling to meet with me at all. Not being compensated for the same job that other people do due to a technicality is not great, and the unwillingness of management to work with me was a horrible experience.  

Scheduling was also a disaster, not just the training schedule but scheduling in general. You can see preferential treatment so blatantly. 

Also, there has to be a better system to grab files. Where they keep files is far and very remote, one feels unsafe if retreval is needed during the night shift.

pros: Friendly people good work environment
cons: stressful hours and low average pay

pros: The people that I work with are very personable. There are free courses that Sunnybrook offers to encourage leadership building. There is a perk site that employees can use to purchase tickets for different events, like musicals, cineplex movie tickets, dave and busters etc. There is a free gym and shuttles that can be used by employees.
cons:
Some challenges of working here are some of the people that you work with. However, wherever you go there will always be challenges with working with certain people. Also, it is difficult to achieve a higher position due to the minimal openings of larger positions. Although, this may be true everywhere else as well. 

On a more serious note, there are times when the management isn't completely fair to all people and take the sides of favorable people.

pros: The hospital values its employees, providing wellness seminars, supplementary medical coverage, and hosting annual employee appreciation bbqs, etc.  You are in an environment where you can interact with patients, their families, nurses that care for the former, and young and elderly volunteers.  It is a humbling experience (if you keep your eyes and heart open).
cons:
Transportation to Sunnybrook is an ongoing problem.  As an employee, either you drive in (after waiting months for a parking spot) and pay a lot of money for parking, or you take the TTC bus (no direct subway access).  Also, I wish Sunnybrook did not slam patients' families with massive parking fees. 

Food availability is also a challenge.  I wish they had the old-style canteen.  Now their fast-food-style cafeterias are high priced, hitting both employees and visitors where it hurts.

review_title: Many overworked employees who have given up hope
job_title: Secretary to Medical Staff in Toronto, ON
pros: Plenty of full-time job opportunities with benefits. Friendly staff members and an overall good community of coworkers.
cons: Archaic filing systems with a number of understaffed units. This could be said for most jobs but depending on whom your supervisor is, it will greatly effect your working conditions and whether or not you will have a happy work life. There seems to be a huge gap in communication between upper management and staff members. Each level seems to advocate for their own agenda, leaving lower level employees at a loss. This in turn causes a high level of turnovers in positions where they are understaffed and overworked.

review_title: Interesting, Wonderful Learning Experience for Co-op/Intern Student
pros:
-Opportunity to improve research and critical thinking skills.
-Promotes interest in human physiology and medical devices.
-Can open doors to future career opportunities in bio-medical devices.
-Variety of projects available (dependent on supervisor).
-Limited supervision gives you the chance to practice independent working skills.
-Flexible hours are a "Pro" in helping to get projects done, if time is used wisely.
cons:
-Flexible hours are a "Con" in maintaining a work-life balance
-Project progression is somewhat slow; just the nature of a research environment as opposed to a business one.
-If you don't have an interest in bio-medical devices, and you already have 2+ years of R&D work experience (regardless of what field), then there is little more to offer here.

review_title: Great and well rounded learning experience
pros: It’s a trauma centre so if you are in trauma you definitely experience a lot. Lots of teaching moments. Teaching hospital with amazing doctors. The best place to be. Nurses are well trained and the care is excellent. The hospital provides room for growth by offering Educational bursaries etc.
cons: There is a Clique system within the units. It can be hard to fit in sometimes as a new comer. The hospital is always in overflow. Hallway patients are becoming the normal. 6-7 patient ratios at night, very exhausting and demanding depending on the clinical area. Still mainly on paper documentation, needs serious upgrade into the digital world.

pros: Great facilities. Lots of great research and very practical projects. Compared to pure academic research, Sunnybrook encourages his staff to do research with a strong focus on knowledge translation and direct clinical applications. Being within the hospital site also helps having access to data, patient and clinician's expertise to accelerate the development of a variety of research projects.
cons: Like any other large hospital institutions, there is a little too much bureaucracy involved with respect to having access to certain data or facilities, and certain technical resources can sometimes be hard to reach. Due to high securities, remote work can also be very difficult as access the Sunnybrook network requires a lot permissions.

pros: In the heart of the city , good hospital , big organization room to grow ( but not at OCC department )  might have better departments  but again but NOT at OCC
cons: Please put people in managerial position if they really have the quality for it !!!

review_title: make sure you have a nice boss - mine was terrible
pros: The hospital is clean, high tech, everyone goes to the Tim Hortons stations, there are workshops, and hallway bazaars on some days.
cons: You really have to watch your back. The culture is friendly on the surface but very political behind the scenes with a cold and haughty upper management and backstabbing colleagues. Of all my hospital jobs this was my most boring admin job and I did not achieve or progress as much as at other hospitals. The work was routine, mundane, heavy on scheduling and meetings, and not fulfilling. I think some of the overly positive reviews on this site are fake.

review_title: My experience has been a fulfilling one.
job_title: Registered Practical Nurse in Toronto, ON
pros: Some of the pros of this facility are the employees.  They are all nice and welcoming. They are alway willing to help and point you in the right direction.
cons: A con about this facility are the parking fees. I feel that it is the most expensive that I've experienced.  Also there is only one cafeteria area In the main wing of the hospital. Hard to get to if you are in another wing and only have 30 mins for break.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Great salary and benefits, a fantastic place for a first HR job, so much to learn from everyone on the team. Also great knowing you are helping and supporting staff that are caring for patients. Great job satisfaction.Loved my time at SB!
cons: Limited opportunity for growth and promotion. But you learn so much it doesn't really matter. The exposure allows you to gain the knowledge to move on to other opportunities.

pros: Large workplace.  Benefits are great.  Scenic.
cons: CYA.  Culture of blame.  Passive-aggressive behavior. Not being a clear communicator.  No process.  No systems.  If administrative mistakes are made, no correction and results in cover up or blaming without improvement.  Results in not knowing expectations.

pros: Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre was a great place to work. I would highly recommend this hospital to patients and to those looking for a career in health care.
cons: It is difficult for me to think of any down sides to working at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre. There is room for improvement in middle management.

review_title: Generally good place to work, a few bad mgrs
pros: Big organization, good healthcare resource reputation, room to move around, lots of employee fringe benefits, average pay, easy to get to by transit, nice facility. Good doctors. Clinical staff are very dedicated.
cons: Hierarchy, politics, not all managers are nice there and its old boys network. Evidence of corruption and waste in the areas of building facility construction.

pros: Sunnybrook Health Centre is a very good organization. Great people and culture. I enjoyed working there and doing my PhD. It is an ideal place to learn about so many topics and work along many smart people.
cons: The only issue with Sunnybrook Health Centre is the commute. It isn't located by a subway stop so you have to take a bus to get there and it can be very crowded during rush hour.

review_title: Good name to have on your resume
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Amazing environment being the largest research hospital in Canada 
-Good knowledgeable specialist physicians 
-Open environment
-People generally are willing to help you learn or contribute on projects
cons:
-Teaching hospital so not everything is as efficient as it could be
-Massive organizational challenges you find with any large organization
-

review_title: Good experience for growth, but few opportunities for salary increases
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: Very great institutional attitude towards research. Everyone is very helpful. I’ve experienced a lot of growth during the 2 years I’ve spent here. I’ve had a lot of opportunities to take on more responsibilities and handle larger projects.
cons: Little opportunity for raises, and very small raises are offered. Infrequent performance reviews.

review_title: Able to get good experience working in a research environment.
pros: Sunnybrook Research Institute at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre provides a good environment for doing research work in the field of medical imaging. It is one of the top research institutes of its kind in the world.
cons: The payscale as a research engineer was a bit on the lower end given postgraduate degree and work experience, but is understandable for an academic environment.

review_title: Little Fish in a Big Lake
pros: Felt good being a part of a large well run organization.   Excellent pay and benefits. Ongoing training available.  Depending on the unit (or supervisor), the ability to switch shifts therefore less sick calls.
cons: Micromanagement by inept supervisors. Higher management should investigate supervisors with a history of loosing good workers.

pros: They provide excellent health care, and in the end, that's what's important.
cons: Very bad work environment. Their respect policy isn't worth the paper it's printed on. Management here, like so many other places, seem to think their budgeting woes can be solved by cutbacks. Meanwhile, the work duties get reshuffled onto staff that is already spread too thin. Mid to upper level management use the same method for cutting lower management too, leaving their lower management spread too thin and ineffective in managing their departments. Meanwhile, much of their full-time staff rest on their laurels and pass off the work to the part-time and casual staff. They are relied upon for payroll and scheduling duties. The strict scheduling rules are completely ignored and the payroll is too complicated and rests in too many hands leaving people to chase down their pay for each and every pay period. The union is useless. They are only interested in collecting their dues and pay no attention to how their members' rights have been ignored - either between staff members or staff and management. Both management and the union are ignorant of basic Labour code and disregard the ones they do know in hopes of getting away with it.

pros:
Opportunity to contribute to a worthy cause.
Supportive coworkers.
cons:
No opportunities for growth or advancement.  Employees are put in a box on their first day and expected to stay there.
Hierarchical structure where you are treated better based on your title.
High rate of turnover has led to lower morale.

job_title: Patient Administrative Associate in Toronto, ON
pros:
Flexible shift hours 
Training provided 
Large company with many different areas to find shift work 
respectful environment and co-workers
cons: Very difficult to get full time, not based on performance or qualifications, but rather seignority unfortunately

review_title: Good place in Ontario to work
job_title: PACU RN OR Perm Full Time in Toronto, ON
pros: Professional atmosphere, collaboration, staff is great!
cons: Parking is expensive and scarce.  More opportunities to continue education on site and at varied times. Increase the number of nurse led instructors.

pros: Sunnybrook, except for the PMO is a very good organization to work for. My review is specific to the PMO.
cons:
Poor Project Management. Finger pointing culture.
A Business Analyst is like a secretary, expected to do what a PM says. A BA does not acquire any relevant BA skill sets, such as UML, Requirement Gathering etc.
No growth opportunities whatsover. Growth of any kind whether it is lateral, vertical or just in terms of accountabilities is absent.
I would not recommend working there.

pros: Good vacation - 3 weeks + 2 Lieu Day, 18 days of maximum sick days, good, dedicated, bright co-workers, love what they do in terms of research and finding novel medical treatments.
cons: Severely underpaid, over worked. Overpriced parking.

job_title: Diagnostic Cardiac Sonographer in Toronto, ON
pros: I’ve been at Sunnybrook since graduation in 1984, and am now transitioning to the SRI (Research Institute).  Cannot imagine working anywhere else.  Innovative, supportive, collaborative, friendly, encouraging, brilliant people who are like family.  Live your professional career dreams here!
cons: Parking is expensive, but where isn’t parking expensive in Toronto??

review_title: Review of Sunnybrook Hospital Research Institute
pros: Benefits are great, access to educational seminars, staff appreciation events, in general Sunnybrook has a friendly & approachable staff atmosphere.
cons: Commute and parking, access to senior management difficult at times.

pros: Great health and dental benefits + eligible to enrol in the HOOP pension plan. Hours can be flexible to a extent.
cons: The commute through Bayview Ave is painful , work load can be high , not a lot of growth within the organization

job_title: Patient Administrative Associate in Toronto, ON
pros: Benefits were great, the staff and environment was good. Overall it was an excellent place to work
cons: Every place as it stress, patients are very sick so take nothing personal. Long hours not enough pay for what I did

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: Great benefit and pension plans for full-time employees - even if only temporary!
cons: It really depends who your direct supervisor/boss is in regards to the job specifics. Takes a really long time to get to Sunnybrook by transit and by car.

review_title: Casual Porter for mess of a department
pros:
- Good Pay
- Lot of shifts
- Good workout
cons:

- higher expectations than other hospitals

review_title: Supportive scientists and clinicians who create an engaging work environment
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Toronto, ON
pros: Strong sense of community, very friendly people, senior staff are willing to provide generous advice and support.
cons: Administrative aspects and hoops you need to jump through to do routine tasks during research can be challenging.

pros: Sunnybrook has a great working environment, especially from a research perspective. Lots of smart people, and opportunities of collaboration and networking. The work life balance is also great. Overall, a really nice place to work at.
cons: Not much, maybe better compensation

pros: Lots of professional and personal development opportunities. Beautiful hospital setting.
cons: Lack of communication. Often felt very lonely working there, even when surrounded by people. Morale isn't great.

pros: Decent starting salary, good benefits and vacation, lots of courses offered internally to take online or through in-class instructor led courses.
cons: The work life balance is OK, not many opportunities to grow and take on other responsibilities as you develop new skills.

pros: lots of free perks from different vendors, summer BBQ, pretty laidback, 100% employer paid on benefits, HOOPP, work life balance, stable
cons: micromanaging, no growth, no work from home

job_title: Team Lead-Medical Imaging in Toronto, ON
pros: It is an acedemic institution.
cons: Large organisation, less growth oppurtinites

pros:
lots of opportunities to learn through workshops
flex hours
work was engaging and supervisor was great as guiding and giving constructive criticism
cons: the pay was lower than average but I think the experience was worth it

pros: Place is full of great people to work with and theres always opportunity to personally develop if your motivated
cons: Some departments are highly disorganized and can hurt your career development

pros: Very supportive staff and a very positive learning experience as a new nursing graduate.
cons: The work environment is a very fast-paced and high stress environment but the staff and managers are very supportive.

review_title: Negative experience for new grad RN
pros: Salary, benefits, flexibility of shift schedulling
cons: Management, politics, ++horizontal violence (RN to RN bullying)

pros: Great place to work.  Amazing patients.
cons: Some people in higher positions can be too assertive and when it's reported, there is no change.

job_title: Patient Administrative Associate in Toronto, ON
pros: Lots of learning opportunities, chances for communication with many interdisciplinary services.
cons: Management is a brick wall, suggestions from staff ignored.

review_title: It's an okay place to work but not for the long-term

pros: Well regarded research institution with direct access to clinical research
cons: Bureaucracy and at times a narrow vision for the research departments at Sunnybrook

review_title: Great experience for a first job

review_title: Great place to work, difficult to advance in position as not many job opportunities open up.
job_title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: Great reputation, works well as a team.
cons: Hospital administration and hierarchy can make things difficult for you to grow.

pros: The management within the information services sector is superb. You are encouraged to learn, expand your skills, and bring new ideas to the table.

review_title: I had an amazing experience here. I miss working here but it was my time to move on. Management is organized!

pros: Location, autonomy, great client population, great surgeons and reputation

pros: Having access to several labs with multiple techniques
